title: R44430
content: The Office on Violence Against Women (OVW) administers programs under the Violence Against Women Act (VAWA) to improve criminal justice responses to domestic violence, dating violence, sexual assault, and stalking. The Obama Administration's FY2017 request for OVW was $489 million, with proposed increases for various grants to combat different forms of violence. The Obama Administration proposed funding increases for various grants under the Office on Violence Against Women (OVW), including grants for campuses, combatting abuse against the elderly, and strengthening tribal justice systems' response to domestic violence. Congress adopted a $326 million transfer from the Crime Victims Fund for OVW in the Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2017, but largely did not support the rest of the Administration's proposals. Funding for grants to encourage arrests in domestic violence cases and enforce protection orders was increased, but not at the level proposed. Congress did not fully support the Obama Administration's proposals for funding increases in grants related to domestic violence. Funding for grants to encourage arrests in domestic violence cases and enforce protection orders was increased, but not to the extent proposed. The Office of Justice Programs manages various grant programs, including STOP grants, which were funded at the same level as the previous year in FY2017. The Research, Evaluation, and Statistics account saw a requested increase of 32.8% for FY2017, with a focus on funding for the Bureau of Justice Statistics and the National Institute of Justice. The Obama Administration requested a $154 million budget for FY2017 for the Research, Evaluation, and Statistics account, with increases in funding for the Bureau of Justice Statistics and the National Institute of Justice. Congress provided $89 million for this account, a decrease of 23.3% from the previous year, mainly due to funding being moved to the Community Oriented Policing Services account. The Obama Administration's FY2017 request for the State and Local Law Enforcement Assistance account was $1.098 billion, a 22.1% decrease from the previous year. Funding for programs like the Edward Byrne Memorial JAG program, Drug Courts program, and DNA backlog reduction grant programs were included. The Administration proposed cuts to programs like the State Criminal Alien Assistance Program and grants for trafficking victims, while maintaining funding for grants to assist trafficking. The Obama Administration proposed cuts to various programs in the State and Local Law Enforcement Assistance account for FY2017, including reductions in funding for the JAG program, National Criminal History Improvement program, and DNA backlog reduction initiatives. However, there were also proposed increases in funding for reentry initiatives, programs for children exposed to violence, and grants for residential programs. The Obama Administration proposed reducing funding for various programs under the State and Local Law Enforcement Assistance account for FY2017. However, they also suggested increasing funding for reentry initiatives, programs for children exposed to violence, grants for residential substance abuse treatment, and programs to assist people with mental illness in the criminal justice system. Additionally, new programs were requested, including funding for the Byrne Incentive Grant program, Byrne Competitive Grant program, and grants for courts and justice agencies to improve fairness perception. The grant program aims to implement evidence-based strategies on national issues, providing $20 million for grants to improve fairness perception in justice systems and build community trust, $5 million for the Violence Reduction Network, and $6 million for grants to counter violent extremism. Congress reduced funding for State and Local Law Enforcement Assistance by 9.1% for FY2017, reallocating funds to specific programs under the JAG program. Congress reduced funding for the JAG program by $73 million for FY2017, resulting in a decrease in available funding from $347 million to $335 million. The Consolidated Appropriations Act eliminated $30 million in funding for tribal assistance programs but authorized the use of up to 7% of funding from other accounts for tribal justice assistance programs. Additionally, $103 million was provided for an opioid initiative, with funding coming from various existing programs. The funding for the initiative comes from various existing programs, including Drug Courts, Veterans Treatment Courts, Residential Substance Abuse Treatment, Prescription Drug Monitoring, and programs for individuals with mental illness in the criminal justice system. Congress provided $13 million for programs under the opioids initiative, but declined to fund new programs proposed by the Obama Administration. The Juvenile Justice Programs account includes funding for grant programs to reduce juvenile delinquency and improve juvenile justice systems. The Obama Administration requested $334 million for the Juvenile Justice Programs account in FY2017, with increases for various grant programs to reduce juvenile delinquency. This included funding for the Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act, Title V grants, and the Community-based Violence Prevention Initiative. Additionally, funding was proposed to be restored for Juvenile Accountability Block Grants and a Smart on Juvenile Justice Initiative. However, there were proposed reductions in funding for youth mentoring grants, investigation and prosecution of child abuse programs, and the missing and exploited children program. Congress appropriated $247 million for the Juvenile Justice Programs account for FY2017, with reductions in funding for various programs including youth mentoring grants, investigation and prosecution of child abuse programs, and the missing and exploited children program. Additionally, Congress declined to fund new programs proposed by the Obama Administration and chose to fund the Community-based Violence Prevention Initiative as a set-aside from the Title V grant program. The Community Oriented Policing Services (COPS) Office awards grants to law enforcement agencies for hiring new officers, training in community policing, and deploying crime-fighting technologies. The COPS Office awards grants to law enforcement agencies for hiring new officers, training in community policing, and deploying crime-fighting technologies. The Obama Administration requested a $74 million increase in funding for COPS in FY2017. Congress appropriated $222 million for COPS in FY2017, with a 4.5% increase in funding compared to FY2016. Funding for the COPS hiring program remained unchanged at $137 million after set-asides. Congress also provided a $3 million increase in funding for the Anti-heroin Task Forces. Congress increased funding for the COPS hiring program to $195 million, but actual funding remained at $137 million after set-asides. An additional $3 million was allocated for the Anti-heroin Task Forces program. Funding for the Regional Information Sharing System (RISS) under the COPS account was transferred to OJP. $8 million was set aside for the POLICE Act of 2016, allowing COPS grants to be used for active shooter training. The Administration's FY2017 budget requested $500 million for the 21st Century Justice Initiative, a new program aimed at criminal justice reform efforts. The initiative aimed to use federal funding for innovative approaches to reduce crime and unnecessary incarceration, focusing on three objectives: reducing crime, reversing practices leading to long sentences and unnecessary incarceration, and building community trust. States could use the funding for various objectives such as changing laws, promoting community policing, and providing diversion and reentry services. Additionally, 10% of the funding would be dedicated to reform efforts in the federal criminal justice system. However, Congress did not provide funding for this program.
